body:
This is the output of the test run: 
bash-3.2$ /Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/Resources/Python.app/Contents/MacOS/Python /Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/site-packages/IPython/testing/iptest.py IPython.lib
..........................F...........................S....
======================================================================
FAIL: Test the IPython runner.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/site-packages/IPython/lib/tests/test_irunner.py", line 136, in testIPython
    self._test_runner(runner,source,output)
  File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/site-packages/IPython/lib/tests/test_irunner.py", line 46, in _test_runner
    self.fail(message)
AssertionError: Mismatch in number of lines
Expected:
~~~~~~~~~
In [1]: print 'hello, this is python'
hello, this is python
# some more code
In [2]: x=1;y=2
In [3]: x+y**2
Out[3]: 5
# An example of autocall functionality
In [4]: from math import *
In [5]: autocall 1
Automatic calling is: Smart
In [6]: cos pi
------> cos(pi)
Out[6]: -1.0
In [7]: autocall 0
Automatic calling is: OFF
In [8]: cos pi
   File "", line 1
     cos pi
          ^
SyntaxError: invalid syntax
In [9]: cos(pi)
Out[9]: -1.0
In [10]: for i in range(5):
   ....:     print i
   ....:
0
1
2
3
4
In [11]: print "that's all folks!"
that's all folks!
In [12]: exit
Got:
~~~~~~~~~
In [1]: print 'hello, this is python'
  File "", line 1
    print 'hello, this is python'
                                ^
SyntaxError: invalid syntax
# some more code
In [2]: x=1;y=2
In [3]: x+y**2
Out[3]: 5
# An example of autocall functionality
In [4]: from math import *
In [5]: autocall 1
Automatic calling is: Smart
In [6]: cos pi
------> cos(pi)
Out[6]: -1.0
In [7]: autocall 0
Automatic calling is: OFF
In [8]: cos pi
  File "", line 1
    cos pi
         ^
SyntaxError: invalid syntax
In [9]: cos(pi)
Out[9]: -1.0
In [10]: for i in range(5):
   ....:     print i
   ....: 
  File "", line 2
    print i
          ^
SyntaxError: invalid syntax
In [11]: print "that's all folks!"
  File "", line 1
    print "that's all folks!"
                            ^
SyntaxError: invalid syntax
In [12]: exit
    """Fail immediately, with the given message."""
>>  raise self.failureException('Mismatch in number of lines\n\nExpected:\n~~~~~~~~~\nIn [1]: print \'hello, this is python\'\nhello, this is python\n# some more code\nIn [2]: x=1;y=2\nIn [3]: x+y**2\nOut[3]: 5\n# An example of autocall functionality\nIn [4]: from math import *\nIn [5]: autocall 1\nAutomatic calling is: Smart\nIn [6]: cos pi\n------> cos(pi)\nOut[6]: -1.0\nIn [7]: autocall 0\nAutomatic calling is: OFF\nIn [8]: cos pi\n   File "", line 1\n     cos pi\n          ^\nSyntaxError: invalid syntax\nIn [9]: cos(pi)\nOut[9]: -1.0\nIn [10]: for i in range(5):\n   ....:     print i\n   ....:\n0\n1\n2\n3\n4\nIn [11]: print "that\'s all folks!"\nthat\'s all folks!\nIn [12]: exit\n\nGot:\n~~~~~~~~~\nIn [1]: print \'hello, this is python\'\n  File "", line 1\n    print \'hello, this is python\'\n                                ^\nSyntaxError: invalid syntax\n# some more code\nIn [2]: x=1;y=2\nIn [3]: x+y**2\nOut[3]: 5\n# An example of autocall functionality\nIn [4]: from math import *\nIn [5]: autocall 1\nAutomatic calling is: Smart\nIn [6]: cos pi\n------> cos(pi)\nOut[6]: -1.0\nIn [7]: autocall 0\nAutomatic calling is: OFF\nIn [8]: cos pi\n  File "", line 1\n    cos pi\n         ^\nSyntaxError: invalid syntax\nIn [9]: cos(pi)\nOut[9]: -1.0\nIn [10]: for i in range(5):\n   ....:     print i\n   ....: \n  File "", line 2\n    print i\n          ^\nSyntaxError: invalid syntax\nIn [11]: print "that\'s all folks!"\n  File "", line 1\n    print "that\'s all folks!"\n                            ^\nSyntaxError: invalid syntax\nIn [12]: exit')
    
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 59 tests in 19.666s
FAILED (SKIP=1, failures=1)

In each version of IPython, what do you get from:

```
from IPython.lib import irunner
irunner._ipython_cmd
```

Also, can you confirm that `ipython` starts with Python 2.7, and `ipython3` starts with Python 3.3?

Oh, I see the problem.

In Python 3.3.2 it reports 'ipython3', in 2.7.5 it reports 'ipython'. But I have /usr/local/bin/ipython as a link to /Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.3/bin/ipython3 as I want my Python stuff to be default Python3.

I only use Python2 when I need something that isn't supported in Python 3, or to test some legacy code.

Wouldn't it be better if irunner._ipython_cmd would be /Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/bin/ipython instead in 2.7.5 (and /Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.3/bin/ipython3 in 3.3.2) or the equivalent in other OS's?
Or like it's done in IPython.testing.tools?

Yes, I think we should change it to use `python -m IPython` where python is sys.executable. We couldn't do that until now because it didn't work in 2.6, but I'll add it to PR #4002 where we're dropping 2.6 support.
If you've got the time, can you try with my drop-26-32 branch from PR #4002?
I installed your drop-26-32  version in Python 2.7.5 and it passes all tests.

Great, thanks.

On 14 August 2013 21:22, pietvo notifications@github.com wrote:

> I installed your drop-26-32 version in Python 2.7.5 and it passes all
> tests.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/4013#issuecomment-22684441
> .
